1022698.name: Mask Strap Ear Saver
1022698.notes_html:
This is a free pattern for a face mask strap / ear saver.

My cousin, an ER nurse, asked me to make surgical mask straps for her and her fellow RNs, as their ears were getting sore and abraded from the constant need to wear a surgical mask. I came up with this easy crochet strap pattern. I used I Love This Cotton, but you can use any aran weight cotton yarn.

Supplies: Cotton yarn, Buttons, Yarn needle, Scissors, and a thinner yarn to sew on the buttons. I used a sport weight yarn to sew on the buttons.

users.about_me:
I'm a wife, mother of four kids and mimi to three littles. I have six sisters, but no brothers. I've been a freelance court reporter for over 20 years, and most days I really like my job! I'm a city girl, born and raised in Philadelphia, but I love the country.  I love to travel, although I can't afford to do it often.  I've been to Ireland three times, and if it's in the cards, the dream is to retire there some day. And of course...I love to crochet!! I learned to crochet when I was around 10 years old and crocheted here and there over the years...but it wasn't until five or six years ago that it became a daily thing/obsession. "What are you making NOW?" is something I hear regularly from my husband. ;) 

I finally taught myself to knit a couple years ago. I’d tried and failed so many times in the past, but I’ve finally gotten the hang of it!  So crochet is mostly on the back burner for me now while I work to increase my skill at knitting.

I’ve been to Ireland three times, and if it’s in the cards, the dream is to retire there some day. And of course…I love to crochet!! I learned to crochet when I was around 10 years old and crocheted here and there over the years…but it wasn’t until five or six years ago that it became a daily thing/obsession. “What are you making NOW?” is something I hear regularly from my husband. ;)

I finally taught myself to knit a couple years ago. I’d tried and failed so many times in the past, but I’ve finally gotten the hang of it! So crochet is mostly on the back burner for me now while I work to increase my skill at knitting.

1023256.name: Ear Savers, Face Mask Straps
1023256.notes_html:
Proceeds from the pattern sale will be used for supplies so I can continue to make these bands and donate them to my local nurses. Thank you for the continued support.

I am so grateful to all the first responders who are reporting to work everyday. They have been working long shifts and constantly wearing face masks to keep themselves and others healthy. With the constant use of the face masks, the elastics have been causing chafing, which as you can imagine is causing a lot of discomfort. I had a friend ask if I could make these and of course jumped at the chance to help.

I am sharing the pattern with you in hopes you would consider donating them to your local nurses.

How to use:
The purpose of these are to help save your ears from the pain of the face mask elastics. Instead place the elastics around the buttons.

Disclosure:
These items DO NOT mitigate, prevent, treat, diagnose or cure any disease or health condition.

pattern_author.name: MyHobbyShop
pattern_author.notes:
My name is Lily. I learned to crochet as a child. The first item I remember completing was a baby blanket. I didn't follow a pattern simply let the hook and needle guide my hands. This is how I crocheted for decades. When my children would go to bed I would retreat to the couch where I would mindlessly crochet for hours while watching TV. After a while all my friends and family had enough hats, scarves and blankets! That's when I discovered Etsy.


Etsy become a platform for me to not only sell my handmade items but meet some amazing artist. I was overwhelmed with all the talent that was collected under one place. The last eleven years on Etsy has been a roller coaster ride. I have learned and accomplished so many things that have changes how I designs and make my art as well as sell.


I wanted to start 2020 with something new and exciting. I started my own  website to share my passion. Whether you are an artist yourself or a customer who truly appreciated handmade items, my hope is that we can connect and inspire one another.
pattern_author.notes_html:

This is how I crocheted for decades. When my children would go to bed I would retreat to the couch where I would mindlessly crochet for hours while watching TV. After a while all my friends and family had enough hats, scarves and blankets! That’s when I discovered Etsy.

Etsy become a platform for me to not only sell my handmade items but meet some amazing artist. I was overwhelmed with all the talent that was collected under one place. The last eleven years on Etsy has been a roller coaster ride. I have learned and accomplished so many things that have changes how I designs and make my art as well as sell.

I wanted to start 2020 with something new and exciting. I started my own website to share my passion. Whether you are an artist yourself or a customer who truly appreciated handmade items, my hope is that we can connect and inspire one another.

1023334.name: Healthcare headbands
1023334.gauge_description: 20 stitches and 26 rows = 4 inches in not important
1023334.notes_html: I learned that healthcare workers were requesting headbands with buttons so that they could attach the elastics from facemasks to the buttons and relieve their ears a bit. I came across a Ravelry pattern by Lynne Christie called Care Workers Special Headband. Her design looked great, however, I tweaked it a bit to avoid garter stitch (not my favorite) and use up stash of Sugar n’ Cream cotton for a lighter weight, more spring/summer - like headband. I have included two slightly different patterns, one narrower and less “lacy” (11 stitches v. 12). I wasn’t sure if they would be effective, but recently received positive feedback from the healthcare workers at my local hospital. Small thing to do for those who are doing such GREAT things at this crazy time

1023398.notes_html: FREE Ear Saver Pattern on my blog. I have been making these for front line essential workers.

1023408.name: Quick Ear Savers
1023408.notes_html:
This pattern is free on my blog, or you can purchase the PDF here!

It’s an unusual time - with new opportunities to help others! One of the things I have done is make Quick Crochet Ear Savers for friends who have to wear masks all day, to make it as comfortable as possible.

There are lots of patterns for these out there - they are quite simple! - but I thought I’d share how I did it, to help as many as possible.

Video tutorial included!

1023573.name: Adjustable Buttonhole Ear Savers for Masks
1023573.notes_html:
Sore ears from those pesky elastic mask straps? This is an adjustable ear saver for masks pattern! It has buttonholes and has a longer strip to accommodate most people and most masks. You can use cotton or acrylic yarn, whatever suits your needs.

Feel free to adjust the pattern as necessary to your particular needs as far as button and buttonhole size, and strip length for head size, etc goes and make it your own style!

Let’s get through this together! Happy and safe crafting everyone! (Kudos to my husband who helped with designing this) <3

Please don’t copy and publish my pattern as your own. Just adjust the length of the strip and buttonhole size to suit your needs. Also, please donate these whenever possible! <3

1024121.name: Face Mask Ear Protector
1024121.notes_html:
This crochet strand has been done as a help for essential workers who is obliged to protect themselves during this hard time by wearing mask. This ear saver will help to relieve the pressure from elastic and will make your day more comfortable.

It is a great 15 min project that can be done as a gift for those one in need.

Level: Beginner

VIDEO TUTORIAL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v54fiSqcVvg

Facebook https://www.facebook.com/groups/crazyhands.net/

https://www.instagram.com/amurushka_amur/

1024356.name: Mask Helpers Two Ways
1024356.notes_html:
Mask Helpers are a great way to keep elastic off of the ears to reduce soreness after wearing face masks for a long period of time. Easy to stitch crochet strips have a button on either side to hook the elastic mask loops on. This pattern and video has two versions of the helpers…a vertically stitched “stretchy” version and a horizontally stitched “sturdy” version. A great project to make for personal use, but also consider donating them as well!

Want a little help? There’s a full video tutorial too!

1024523.name: Super Quick Ear Savers
1024523.gauge_description: 22 stitches and 24 rows = 4 inches in 2x2 ribbing
1024523.notes_html:
This is a pattern for super quick to knit ‘’ear savers’’ for all the people out there fighting the coronavirus on a daily basis. We’re wearing masks far more often and for longer periods than usual and that might create stress over the ears and chafing. To prevent that, we can attach the ear elastics to the buttons at each end of the knitted piece and it will stretch to fit different adult heads with no problem, as ribbing is quite stretchy.

I’ve tried quite a few different Ear Savers patterns and they were all knit from one small end to the other, so it involved a lot of turning the work around and I thought it maybe could be done a bit quickly because there are a lot of people who could use them!

They’re super beginner friendly too! They’re like tiny scarves you can make over and over and that will be put to good use right after! Plus, I added pictures for some techniques at the end and links to tutorials if you need it.

MATERIALS

  • You’ll need light worsted/worsted/aran/bulky weight or even two strands held together of fingering, sport or dk ACRYLIC or COTTON yarn (work with what you have in your stash! Your fabric might look a bit different, but they’ll all work just fine). I’ve been told that some hospitals and care centres don’t accept acrylic yarn, so make sure to check the requirements of the place or person you’re making it for!

  • Tapestry needle.

  • ¾ to 1 inch buttons (2), OR anything that would work like soda can tabs or bottle caps…

  • Big sewing needle that fits through your button holes and fingering yarn scraps to sew (ideally).

GAUGE
Not very important. Just knit, and have fun! You can test combinations of colors or weights…

SIZES
One size with instructions for modifications included throughout the pattern.

NEEDLES
Size US 7 (4,5mm) for smaller yarn;
Size US 8 (5mm) for bigger yarn.
You might want to adjust if you’re a very tight or very loose knitter. I have a pretty average tension.

YARDAGE
Less than 10 yards should be enough.

I really hope you have fun knitting those. They’re like useful little swatches, and the result doesn’t matter too much, as long as it’s stretchy, so the world is your oyster!!

I know these are very rough times for everyone, so I just wanted to say…
To those on the frontlines, essential workers and people giving time and money to help, THANK YOU!

To those staying home and making all the efforts to protect others, THANK YOU! If we all protect others, we’re protecting ourselves too in the end.

HAVE FUN (AT HOME)!

users.fave_colors: Old pink, mustard, grey, emerald, magenta.
users.about_me: Hi! I was a bramaker until 3 years ago, when I was hospitalized for one full year without going back home. I started to knit after that because I had lost a lot of abilities and I still wanted to do something creative with my hands. I was convinced I wasn't able to knit because, young, I had a lot of coordination issues. But it appears with PT you can do miracles! So now knitting is my main activity and I want to begin sharing with other people the design ideas I have in my head! Join me and let's have fun.

So now knitting is my main activity and I want to begin sharing with other people the design ideas I have in my head! Join me and let’s have fun.

1024922.name: PonyTail Mask Mates Ear Savers
1024922.notes_html:
Use these to put around your pony tail, attach elastics from masks around the buttons to relieve pressure on your ears.

Supplies:
100% Cotton yarn
Size H hook
Needle
2 Buttons
Hair Tie

These are made out of 100% cotton so they can be machine washed on high to clean.

1025176.name: Ear Savers for Masks
1025176.notes_html:
I know these patterns have been a dime a dozen lately, and although there are many nice ones out there I couldn’t find any that were quite what I wanted. The way I designed this one should provide it with limited stretch thanks to the starting chain supporting the middle of the piece. Also the larger buttons help secure the piece for use through a long period of movement with less stress.

I have been making these up like a storm for many healthcare worker friends, essential worker friends, as well as many elderly friends and family, and really anyone else. I have gotten a lot of great feedback on how these are holding up to their constant use and will update as needed if given any other feedback.

This pattern is totally free to download, I only ask that you do not remove my copyright or credits and please do not share it as your own.

In times like these it is important that we all come together to help each other survive both physically and mentally. That being said I am requesting you do not sell any finished product from this pattern, but instead give it away to those who need them. Stay safe everyone!

1025216.name: Ear Saver with kam snaps
1025216.notes_html:
I created this pattern as I wanted to make some ear savers to donate to local healthcare workers, however having no buttons available I could only use what I had at home, which was a box full of Kam snaps!

This pattern is worked entirely in the round from a starting chain and is complete in just 4 rows. It has no set gauge, however I do give the sizes that mine worked up to.

This pattern is adaptable for the length you need by adding to or subtracting from the starting chain if you want, but adding extra snaps to the ear saver makes it adjustable in size too!

I have used Scheepjes River washed and Stone washed mini skeins for this project as I wanted thin yarn so that the snaps would easily join, thicker yarn would prevent the snaps from having a secure bond.

I have managed to get three ear savers from one mini skein.

This is a written pattern only, there is no photographic step by step. However if you are having any issues whatsoever please don’t hesitate to contact me.

You can find me on Instagram and Facebook Sweetlifecrochet

1025418.name: Save Your Ears Face Mask Strap
1025418.notes_html:
We want to do our part by wearing a facemask, but does it have to be so uncomfortable? With only 1 button, but lots of buttonholes for maximum adjustability.

Hopefully you will find this Face Mask Strap a lifesaver. When we are finally able to ditch the facemasks, perhaps you can use your strap as a bracelet.

Finished measurement: Approx. 7-12” depending on weight of fabric and your gauge. If your mask has tight/close fitting closure, you might want to cast on more stitches. If that is the case, increase by 10 st.

With regard to yarn needed for this project, it depends on the weight of your yarn, but estimate less than 3 yards.

Aside from yarn, you will also need a button. We found a 1” button works best, but wait until you are done before selecting the button as yarn weight and gauge will impact the size of the holes.

Samples:
Rainbow colored strap is 12” long and knit with 100% worsted weight cotton.

Raspberry colored strap is 7” long and knit with an Aran weight superwash wool yarn.

Green colored strap is 7” long and knit with a DK weight cotton.

users.about_me:
I'm a self-taught knitter who has enjoyed this craft for more than 30 years.  Now, I teach knitting and love it even more.  There is no greater joy than helping someone else find their spark.  

Please also check out my designs, posted here on Ravelry under FiberGnome.

Aside from teaching and designing, you can find me as a part-time employee at Center of the Yarniverse, Ashland, VA.  

When not knitting, I'm indulging my other obsession - real estate.  

Please check out my stash as pretty much everything is for sale.  PM me if there is something you are interested in.  

NOTE: I have a number of patterns slated to come out. If you are interested in test knitting shawls and cowls please send me a message through Ravelry or sign up on my site.

When not knitting, I’m indulging my other obsession - real estate.

Please check out my stash as pretty much everything is for sale. PM me if there is something you are interested in.

NOTE: I have a number of patterns slated to come out. If you are interested in test knitting shawls and cowls please send me a message through Ravelry or sign up on my site.

1025510.name: Mask Mate for Ponytail
1025510.notes_html:
This ponytail mask mate pattern was designed after I started making mask mates to help prevent ear discomfort from wearing a medical mask for extended periods of times. A friend wears a ponytail at work almost every day & requested one that would fit around her ponytail.

Gauge is not important for this project.

Any worsted weight 100% cotton yarn can be used.
Cotton is highly recommended so these can be sanitized/washed & dried at high temperatures.

Finished length is approximately 7 inches. The length can be easily adjusted by increasing or decreasing the foundation chain.

Supplies:
size G crochet hook
100% cotton yarn
needle
2 buttons (I used 1 inch/25mm)

Stitch Abbreviations:
hdc - half double crochet
sc - single crochet
ch - chain
st - stitch

These are a great way to use up some scrap cotton yarn.

Note: I have added a smaller 2nd pdf. The larger file (Mask Mate for Ponytail 2) is suited for beginners with a photo tutorial. The smaller file (Mask Mate for Ponytail 3) is step by step written instructions with no photos tutorial.

1025521.name: Easy Ear Savers for Face Masks
1025521.sizes_available: 5 inches / 12.7 cm (Note: length is easily adjustable)
1025521.notes_html:
Note: Free PDF pattern download is on my blog, along with a link to the step-by-step Youtube video tutorial!

This 10-minute Ear Savers pattern is a quick and easy DIY project that you can craft in less than 10 minutes for our frontline workers! Make one for a nurse, doctor, health provider, grocery store worker, and others who need to wear face masks on the regular. You are more than welcome to use my free crochet pattern for charity purposes.

The length of your Ear Savers can also be easily adjustable by adding or decreasing stitches in your starting chain. Your tension and use of a larger or smaller hook can also affect the finished size.

This PDF pattern includes instructions to guide you through the entire process with photo references and a link to the free video tutorial on the Sweet Softies Youtube Channel (www.youtube.com/SweetSofties).

~~~

Size:
Length: 5 inches (12.7 centimeters)

Level:
★☆☆☆☆ Beginner

Stitches/Terms (US Terms):
• FO: fasten off
• Ch: chain
• Sl st: slip stitch
• Hdc: half double crochet

Materials:
• Medium weight 4 yarn (Recommended: cotton yarn to prevent stretch)
• 5.00mm crochet hook
• Two buttons (Recommended: 3/4” to 1” to prevent mask straps from slipping)
• Yarn needle
• Scissors

~~~

This pattern is © 2020 Sweet Softies (www.sweetsofties.com). For personal use only. You may not copy, alter, or sell this pattern in any way. You may sell finished items made with this pattern if you credit Sweet Softies as the designer and link to my website. No wholesale.*

www.sweetsofties.com
www.instagram.com/SweetSofties (@SweetSofties)
www.etsy.com/shop/Sylemn
www.facebook.com/SweetSofties
www.youtube.com/SweetSofties
www.pinterest.com/sweetsofties

1025522.name: Face Mask Connector for Ponytailers
1025522.gauge_description: 5.5 stitches and 8 rows = 1 inch in garter stitch
1025522.notes_html:
This is a great way to use up some scraps while helping out those on the front lines. I strongly suggest using cotton, acrylic, or other non-animal fiber so that these can be washed in hot water without risk of felting.

You can easily adjust this connector to be a little longer or shorter, or to enlarge or narrow the ponytail opening. Got stuck? Just contact me!
1025522.notes:

You can easily adjust this connector to be a little longer or shorter, or to enlarge or narrow the ponytail opening.  Got stuck?  Just contact me!

users.about_me:
Wife, mother, professional pattern editor.  I neglect my housework so I can knit and crochet.
Interested in getting your pattern design out to a wider audience?  I can help you make your pattern easy enough for beginners without sacrificing your gorgeous pattern complexity.  I will also check all your math and charts, make sure your sizing and yardage is correct, and help ensure your knitting or crochet pattern is clear, concise, and a joy to use!  I offer grading, schematics, and charts, and I also have discounts for new clients, bulk work, referrals, and testimonials.  Go to [YarnEdit.Tech][1] to find out more!


  [1]: https://www.yarnedit.tech

1025827.name: Ear Savers
1025827.notes_html: If you run out of elastic while sewing face masks; use the tutorial below to DIY some crochet “elastic”. Then make some ear savers in one of three different styles using these free crochet patterns.
1025827.notes: If you run out of elastic while sewing face masks; use the tutorial below to DIY some crochet “elastic”. Then make some ear savers in one of three different styles using these free crochet patterns.

1025833.name: No Buttons Required Ear Savers
1025833.notes_html:
A few weeks ago I became aware of the need for “ear savers” for front-line medical workers on the coronavirus pandemic. Workers develop wounds behind their ears from wearing masks so much. Crafters developed “ear savers” or “mask mates” that sit on the back of the head and have buttons to secure the straps around, thus saving workers’ ears.

It’s been amazing to see the world come together in support. Knitters, crocheters, and seamstresses have been working tirelessly to produce these. People are 3d printing them, too. I’ve been making lots of them, and I ordered some buttons, but they won’t get here for another couple weeks (for obvious shipping delay reasons because, you know, pandemic). I didn’t want to wait that long to start donating them, though. So I started searching for alternatives to buttons and this is what I came up with. Nothing revolutionary, just my take on the ear savers pattern. Do what you will with them and let me know if I can be of any help.
1025833.notes:
A few weeks ago I became aware of the need for “ear savers” for front-line medical workers on the coronavirus pandemic. Workers develop wounds behind their ears from wearing masks so much. Crafters developed “ear savers” or “mask mates” that sit on the back of the head and have buttons to secure the straps around, thus saving workers’ ears.

It’s been amazing to see the world come together in support. Knitters, crocheters, and seamstresses have been working tirelessly to produce these. People are 3d printing them, too. I’ve been making lots of them, and I ordered some buttons, but they won’t get here for another couple weeks (for obvious shipping delay reasons because, you know, pandemic). I didn’t want to wait that long to start donating them, though. So I started searching for alternatives to buttons and this is what I came up with. Nothing revolutionary, just my take on the ear savers pattern. Do what you will with them and let me know if I can be of any help.

pattern_author.name: Claire Olivia Golden
pattern_author.notes:
Hi, I'm Claire Olivia! I'm a crochet designer, author, housewife, and cat mom to a 5-year-old tortoiseshell cat named Persephone. Life is more fun when you get excited about the little things.

I taught myself to crochet when I was 14 years old with the sole purpose of making stuffed animals, and almost a decade later, that's still my favorite thing to make. I began designing professionally in 2012 and my work has been published in *Crochetvolution*, Crochet Spot, and KnitCrate. I have a B.A. in French and English from Portland State University. 

I'm also an author! My books *Unraveled*, *The Lost Girl of Goose Creek*, and poetry collections are available from Pigeon Press.

Unfortunately for my yarn stash, I am allergic to wool.

1026116.name: Ear Savers
1026116.notes_html:
Pattern makes a 10cm/4” long 4cm/1.5” ear saver. Instructions on how to tweak size are included.

2 buttons per ear saver required 15-25mm diameter

One 10g ball of Catona makes three ear savers with approx. 2g to spare
1026116.notes:
Pattern makes a 10cm/4" long 4cm/1.5" ear saver. Instructions on how to tweak size are included. 

2 buttons per ear saver required 15-25mm diameter

One 10g ball of Catona makes three ear savers with approx. 2g to spare

users.about_me: A leftie, happiest when I’m growing my own, cooking and especially crafting, particularly in fibre arts. My seamstress Grandma taught me to hand stitch in school holidays when I was little. As I got older, I remained creative but school, university, work and three kids left little time for crafting. My girls of course grew and became more independent, then redundancy and later covid, gave me the creative time I craved. I took part in workshops, joined groups of like minded crafters, learned to crochet and returned to stitching and knitting. I studied a Creative Approach to Textiles with the Open College of Arts. Crafting with textiles is a passion, a way of life. Along with a lot of hard work and some luck it has opened the door to a creative career. I now regularly contribute designs to Scheepjes publications and it’s been a real thrill so see my projects in print!

1026548.name: Ruffled Band Mask Mate
1026548.gauge_description: 18 stitches and 10 rows = 4 inches in double crochet
1026548.notes_html: This ruffled band mask mate will help to ease ear strain from wearing a face mask. The project can be adapted to work with different yarns and gauges - the crocheter will just need to adjust the number of stitches within the middle (FPdc) section. Written pattern is avaialbe, though you can also crochet the project with me using a YouTube tutorial!
1026548.notes: This ruffled band mask mate will help to ease ear strain from wearing a face mask. The project can be adapted to work with different yarns and gauges - the crocheter will just need to adjust the number of stitches within the middle (FPdc) section. Written pattern is avaialbe, though you can also crochet the project with me using a YouTube tutorial!

users.about_me:
I have been obsessed with crafting since before I could walk. My Mom and Grandma used to graciously give me supplies, which I would turn into my masterpieces. Over the years, I have experimented with all types of mediums, though I always seem to come back to fiber arts.
I've designed patterns for years, but they were written in my version of shorthand that only I could follow. Now I am updating those patterns and writing new ones to share my love of knitting and crochet with other crafters.
Come check out my blog to see all my creative tutorials and patterns.
users.about_me_html:
I have been obsessed with crafting since before I could walk. My Mom and Grandma used to graciously give me supplies, which I would turn into my masterpieces. Over the years, I have experimented with all types of mediums, though I always seem to come back to fiber arts.
I’ve designed patterns for years, but they were written in my version of shorthand that only I could follow. Now I am updating those patterns and writing new ones to share my love of knitting and crochet with other crafters.
Come check out my blog to see all my creative tutorials and patterns.
